Review
Recent advances in nano-Fenton catalytic degradation of emerging pharmaceutical contaminants
Amit Kumar a,b,c,⁎, Anamika Rana c, Gaurav Sharma a,b, Mu. Naushad d, Pooja Dhiman e, Anu Kumari c, Florian J. Article history: Received 20 February 2019 Received in revised form 9 June 2019 Accepted 11 June 2019 Available online 18 June 2019
The voluminous anthropogenic activities and non-regulated discharge of emerging pharmaceutical pollutants have led to deterioration of water quality characteristics and shortage of potable water. One of most ubiquitous problems is that the pharmaceutical pollutants are slowly developing resistance in pathogens, which increases the risks manifold. Conventional water treatmentmethods and technologies have been known to be inadequate for elimination of recalcitrant and emerging pollutants. Advanced oxidation processes have been exploited to the most for mineralizing the pollutants with some limitations especially toxic metal based catalysts and secondary pollution. However Fenton-based systems are considered to be safer as they utilize non-toxic chemicals. Homogeneous Fenton processes suffer from limitations as limited pH operational range, generation of Fe containing sludge etc. have shifted focus to heterogeneous systems. This review focusses on removal of pharmaceutical pollutants by homogeneous and heterogeneous Fenton, electro-Fenton, sono-Fenton, photo-Fenton and photoelectro-Fenton processes using nano-catalysts. Various types of new pharmaceutical pollutants, their emergence, characteristics and toxicity have been discussed to have an insight into quantity and variety. New Fenton-like catalysts have been designed and used for degradation of pollutants and high mineralization is also achieved in a wide pH-range. In addition Fenton catalysts capable of showing high mineralization using solar light have been prepared by various methods with and without iron based materials. In addition in this review we have also focused on complexities related to removal of pharmaceutical effluents and how they are addressed by Fenton systems. The review aims to assist researchers and engineers to gain fundamental understandings and critical view of Fenton process and its optimization processes, and hopefully with the knowledge it could bring new opportunities for the optimization and future development of Fenton process. The key advances in Fenton catalysts are innovations in design of ligands, junction designing for effective radical generation, reaction engineering, hydro-dynamical effects and complete mineralization. The combinations and coupling of biological oxidation, semiconductor photocatalysis with Fenton process for high performance pharmaceutical pollutants removal in pilot-scale experiments have been discussed and evaluated.

1. Introduction
1.1. Emergence of pharmaceutical products as contaminants
During recent years, numerous organic pollutants have been identified as potential emerging contaminants in the environment with limited literature available [1]. Industrialization and unrestrained use of consumer goods have led to havoc in terms of pollution and energy utilization [2]. A vast number of pharmaceutical products are used worldwide for humans as well as for animals. Although the concentration of these pharmaceuticals residues in the environment is low, its uninterrupted input to the environment may result in the long-term risk for terrestrial and aquatic organisms. From a fewnano-grams to fewmicrograms of these active pharmaceutical ingredients have been found in wastewater treatment plants and also in surface and ground water, which is due to defecation in open or near the water resources as well as due to the overuse of manure as fertilizer [3,4]. Those are considered harmful because many of them are not degraded by various biological treatments used in wastewater treatment plants. They remain untreated even after these treatments for a long time, making them toxic for the environment in both high and low concentrations [5–6].
Many researchers have shown the presence of pharmaceuticals in drinking water [7]. Some published data show that active pharmaceutical ingredients in ground and surface water with 100 ng L−1 concentration and below 50 ng L−1 in drinking water [8]. Pharmaceuticals discharged into the environment possess threat every level in the biological hierarchy, from smaller cells to the larger ecosphere. Out of the various classes of the pharmaceutical, antibiotics are the class, which may cause permanent, long-term,irreversible changes to the genomic texture of the organisms, working as ‘endocrine disruptors’ also known as ‘endocrine disrupting compounds’, causing serious damage to human beings as well as animals [9].
Pharmaceuticals are discharged after application in their native form or as metabolites and enter water frameworks through various ways. The fundamental pathway is ingestion following excretion and disposal through wastewater. Municipal wastewater in this manner is the principle route, bringing human pharmaceuticals into nature. Other major
sources bringing organic pollutants as pharmaceuticals to the environment are hospital wastewaters, wastewater from manufacturers, and landfill leachates [10,11]. Pharmaceuticals usually do not get fully eliminated or degraded in the sewage treatment plant (STP) and then the water containing these pharmaceuticals are being released in treated effluents bringing out the contamination to ponds, rivers, lakes, and, ultimately, back to drinking water as shown in Fig. 1. Along with this, the sewage sludge thrown into agricultural fields also causes soil contamination, which further affects the purity of surface and ground water. In addition, veterinary pharmaceuticalsmay enter ocean systems by applying manure to fields leading to the resulting spillover and another major factor contributing to the increment of veterinary medicines to the ocean system is fish cultivation.
1.2. Types of pharmaceutical contaminants
A number of reports have shown the presence of huge variety of pharmaceuticals in effluents of rivers, sewage sludge, wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) and drinking waters. The term pharmaceuticals refers to a huge and diversified range of drugs, including anticonvulsants and anti-anxiety agents, antibiotics, anti-rheumatics, antiepileptic, analgesics, beta blockers, steroid hormones, and chemotherapeutics as shown in the Table 1 [12,13].
1.2.1. Antibiotics Several studies have shown the existence of antibiotics in wastewa-
ter treatment plants and surfacewater [14–16]. Antibiotics are a class of pharmaceuticals used in prevention and treatment of both human and animals infected with bacterial and fungal infections. Most antibiotics are derived from the natural sources, while some are synthesized artificially (e.g. sulfonamides). A broad variety of antibiotics with different molecular structures has subsequently been found in the environment. Antibiotics consist of varieties of chemicals that can be categorized into different sub-groupswhich includesmacrolides, sulphonamides, quinolones, β-lactams and tetracyclines [17,18]. They are often complex molecules, which may possess different functionalities within the same molecule.

1.2.1.1. β-Lactam antibiotics. β-lactams antibiotics (BLs) are a class of antibiotics, having high chemical reactivity due to the high liability of carbonyl towards nucleophillic attack as well as due to their strained ring structure [19]. BL widely shows antimicrobial activity against both gram-negative and gram-positive organisms. These antibiotics are used as human medicine for the treatment of bacterial infections of skin, ear, respiratory tract, and urinary tract [20]. β-Lactam antibiotics
enclosed in this review include sultamicillin, cefradine, amoxicillin, penicillins G and VK, and ceftriaxone. These b-lactam antibiotics have been originally isolated from molds, such as cephalosporiumacremonium and penicilliumchrysogenum and modified to gain different physicochemical and pharmacological properties. These antibiotics generally inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.
He et al. reported the occurrence of β-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, ampicillin, piperacillin, cephalosporin and cephalothin) and there degradation by using UV-254 nm/H2O2 and UV-254 nm/S2O82−AOPs [21]. Christian et al. reported that AMP, mezlocillin, flucloxacillin, and piperacillin in surface water could be found at concentrations upto 48 ng L−1 [22]. Similarly, Balcioglu and Ötker confirm the occurrence of antibiotic ceftriaxone in formulated wastewater residues [23].
1.2.1.2. Macrolide antibiotics. Macrolide antibiotics are another important class of the antibiotics, which also contributes to the environment pollution heavily. These include various drugs like clarithromycin, erythromycin, azithromycin, and roxithromycin [24]. As reported by McArdell et al., macrolide antibiotics undergo only partial elimination in waste water treatment plants, hence, some amount of these antibiotics are usually found in the environment causing great harm to humans aswell as to animals [25]. In 2009, Okuda et al. found a number of macrolide antibiotics (Azithromycin, Clarithromycin, Roxithromycin, and Tylosin) in Japanese wastewater treatment plants along with other pharmaceuticals [26].
Similarly, the contamination profiles and mass loading of the macrolide antibiotics found in a small wastewater treatment plant was done by Loganathan et al. They found a large quantity of the macrolide antibiotics in small capacity waste water treatment plant having an annual capacity around 5 million gallons [27]. In Switzerland large numbers of macrolide antibiotics and its metabolites were found inwastewater treatment plants and in riverwaterwith concentrations of 0.1–6 μg L−1 [25]. These studies show that the macrolide antibiotic named erythromycin-H2O and some sulfamethoxazole are themajor drugs found in high concentrations in groundwater, seawater as well as in river water samples.
1.2.1.3. Quinolone antibiotics. Quinolone antibiotics, most commonly known as fluoroquinolones (FQ), are broad-spectrum bactericides possess a bicyclic core structure, related to 4-quinolone [28]. These antibiotics are active against many pathogenic bacteria by selectively hindering the synthesis procedure of their DNA. Ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin and other quinolones are used in human medicine [29]. Flumequine, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin are used both as human and animal drugs [30]. Several authors have tried to predict the potential environmental fate [31] and aquatic bacterial toxicity of FQs [32].
Many administered quinolones are largely discharged as unaltered compounds in urine as well as in feces and, consequently, projected into municipal or hospital sewage. Fluoroquinolones as levofloxacin (LFC) enter aquatic bodies as they are resistant to oxidation via microbes and enzymes and thus easily escape conventional water treatment [33]. Out of the various classes of antibiotics, quinolones and tetracyclines form stable complexeswithmetal cations and particulates, which lead to their existence for a long period in the environment. Fluoroquinolone belong to those few pharmaceuticals that have been found in sewage sludges and wastewater effluents [34]. The most used FQs in Switzerland, norfloxacin (NOR) and ciprofloxacin (CIP) were found in the ng L−1 and mg kg−1 level in Swiss wastewater effluents and sewage sludges. Norfloxacin is one of prominent member of FQs family and mostly found in lower concentrations water bodies and high concentration over 100 μg L−1 hospitals wastewater [35]. Trace concentrations of CIP and other antibiotics have also occurred in hospital and municipal wastewaters and in the aquatic environment. A major percentage of CIP was eliminated in the WWTP with by sorption transfer to sewage sludge. The result shows the need of the sewage
sludge management of the human excreta, through which these FQs enter the environment.
Similarly, Bhandari et al. [36] studied the occurrence of CIP (FQs) along with other pharmaceuticals in four different municipal WWTPs. The observation was different for different seasons as summer waste water contains more CIP concentrations than in the winter. Another study conducted by Plosz et al compares the concentration of CIP in hospital effluents andWWTPs effluents in Brazil and the United States. The study revealed higher concentration of CIP in water resources of Brazil as compared to the United States, which may be due to the lack of proper removal technologies in wastewater treatment plants [37]. In
2009, Ghosh et al. studied the occurrence and elimination of the various antibiotics including various fluoroquinolones including ciprofloxacin, enrofloxacin, levofloxacin, nalidixic acid and norfloxacin in four different sewage treatment plants [38].
1.2.1.4. Sulfonamide antibiotics. Sulfonamides (SAs) are group of synthetic antibiotics also called sulfa drugs, usually found at concentrations ranging from 0.13 to 1.9 μg L−1 in various aquatic and terrestrial environments [10]. They belong to a class of antimicrobials with amino benzenesulfonyl structure and target dihydropteroate synthetase [39] and also used as veterinary medicine to treat livestock [40]. In spite of
.
having a common core structure, these usually differ in sulfonamide linkage. A variety of sulfonamides (sulfamerazine, sulfadimethoxine, sulfamoxole, sulfachlopyridazine, sulfadiazine, sulfathiazole, sulfamethazine, sulfamethoxazole, sulfamethizole, and sulfisoxazole) have been synthesized, used and subsequently found in the environment. Due to their toxic effects, they are studied for their degradation by various advanced oxidation processes, semiconductor photocatalysis and ozonation. As a popular SA, Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) has been detected in high concentrations as 24.8 g L−1 (secondary effluents from waste water treatment) and 940 ng L−1 in surface water [41]. SMX is resistant to biological oxidation and escapes easily from conventional water treatment and requires advanced treatment methods for removal. In 2007, Gobel et al. reported the occurrence of in a German waste water treatment plant along with other antibiotics. Upon comparison of various antibiotics found in the WWTP, they found about 94 ± 4% of the SMX and 30–61% of the macrolide antibiotics were degraded during the sewage sludge treatment [42]. Similarly, small amounts of Sulfamethoxazole were found in the Spanish WWTP, out of which about 60% was eliminated during the sewage sludge treatment [43]. Other studies also show that the general biodegradation in the activated sludge treatment can cause 60–80% degradation of sulfonamides. While in some cases there is minor degradation of the sulfonamides as reported by Lindberg et al. [44].
1.2.2. Anticonvulsants and anti-anxiety agents Anticonvulsants, sometimes called antiepileptics, are a group of
pharmaceuticals used in drug therapy to control seizures, treatment of depression, anxiety and mood disorder. Anticonvulsants and antianxiety agents reviewed in this review include carbamazepine, diazepam, oxazepam, and primidone. Based on the research conducted by Pratt et al. in 2014, about 11–12% of the American population (age 12 and above) was addicted to antidepressants and those were among the most commonly used drugs in America in the age group 18–43 years [45]. Similar researches conducted in the same country have shown carbamazepine, gabapentin, and sulpiride are themost detected drugs in the wastewater treatment plants influents and effluents [46–48]. These pharmaceuticals' concentrations range from microgram to the nanogram per litre in the influents and effluents of WWTPs [49–51]. Similar studies carried out in five sewage treatment plants in India have confirmed the presence of antidepressants in STPs. In 2010 Bautit zet al. studied the occurrence and degradation of the anticonvulsant drug (diazepam (DZP)), the most common benzodiazepine drug used as tranquilizer, hypnotic, and muscle relaxant found in sewage treatment plant effluent at 1 μg L−1 in river and in potable water at 10 ng L−1 [52]. Some other anticonvulsant drugs like oxazepam at concentrations around 106–280 ng L−1 show 10% degradation through the Fenton like processes [53]. Other strong anticonvulsant drugs usually found in water resources, having a slow direct photodegradation are also a matter of concern, because their metabolites are more dangerous and persistent in water treatment processes [54,55] and even can be found in higher concentrations than the parent compound [56].
Similarly, Buspirone, another antianxiety agent, was also found in water resources which was treated using TiO2 as a catalyst by Calza et al. [57]. Ding and co-workers utilized CuFeO2-H2O2 Fenton system for degradation of carbamazepine (CBZ) and achieved nearly complete removal of CBZ (50 μM) in 1 h in presence of 0.1 M hydroxylamine. However, only 31% CBZ was removed at pH of 7.0 in the presence with lone CuFeO2+H2O2 system. In presence of hydroxylamine TOC removal increased from10.2% to 91% in 1 h. The reason is attributed to fact that Cu2+ increased ration and enhancement of Fe3+/Fe2+ and Cu2+/ Cu+ redox cycles [58]. The degradation of another anticonvulsant drug Diazepam DZP (25 mg L−1; 88 μM) was performed using zero valent iron (Fe0). In the experiments 96% CBZ removal was observed in after 60 min using Fe0 (25 g L−1) which was pretreated with sulphuric acid and in presence of ethylene diamine tetracaetic acid (119 mg L−1) [59].
1.2.3. β-Blockers Beta (β)-blockers also known as beta-adrenergic blocking agents are
drugs that blocks norepinephrine and epinephrine (adrenaline) from binding to beta receptors on nerves. These aremostly used for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases such as cardiac arrest, congenital heart coronary artery disease, arrhythmias and hypertension. The β-blockers discussed below include atenolol, celiprolol, metoprolol, propranolol, and sotalol. These are among the most used and prescribed drugs in the United States [60] and similarly in Germany, these β-blockers are found in various water resources (about 100–250 tons). In 2011, Sedlak and Pinkston [61], in Germany found the sotalol β-blocker in various water bodies having concentration up to1 μg L−1 [61]. Further findings by Ternes et al. also illustrated the occurrence and degradation of the five beta blockers (celiprolol, propranolol, sotalol, atenolol and metoprolol) found in the effluents of the waste water treatment plants at ng L−1 level [62]. Atenolol (b20 ng L−1) was detected in the surface water of Cuernavaca [63], 83 ng L−1 in river waters and (2 mg L−1) in sewage treatment wastes [64] and also in lower concentrations in some others countries also. Similarly, another beta blocker Metoprolol (0.2–3.1 μg L−1) was also found in the wastewater of Mexico City metropolitan area. In Germany about 100–250 tons per year of the prescribed drugs are disposed in water resources as well as well in waste water treatment plants. Atenolol (ATP) and Metoprolol (MET) are the most found drugs in the wastewater treatment plants, while the levels for propranololwere significantly lower (0.3 and0.1 g L−1, respectively) as compared to the drugsmentioned above,most likely due to the lower use. Ioannou et al. [65] studied the degradation of investigated decomposition of β-blockers (atenolol and propranolol) (10 mg L−1) under simulated solar lightwith commercial TiO2 catalyst. 80% of drugwas degraded in 120min of exposure. The degradation reactionwas favored at neutral pH and no effect was observed on addition of H2O2 [65]. Sotalol also has been classified as an inherently biodegradable compound. As a result, sotalol has frequently been detected in wastewater treatment plants with the concentration up to μg L−1 [66]. This compound also has been found to occur in drinking water at concentrations 0.4–16 ng L−1. The degradation of the sotalol was done through the chlorination process by Khalit et al. which shows that 99% sotalol can be eliminated by using 1 μM chlorine in the selected water samples [67]. Veloutsou et al. [132] degraded ATL (20 mg L−1) and MET drugs using Fe(ClO4)3 + H2O2 under UV radiation with complete reduction in few minutes. The H2O2 concentration used for ATL and MET was 100 mg L−1 and 95 mg L−1 respectively. Both the drugs were not detected within 1 min however complete mineralization was achieved in 150 min [68]. In another experiment MET degradation was studied using photo and photo-fenton degradation process. 90% MET (50mg L−1) degradation was reported using Fe2+ (10mg L−1) without H2O2 after 120 min. During Fenton process using 150 mg L−1 H2O2 and 10mg L−1 Fe2+, 62.8%METwas degradedwithin 10min, howevermineralization was too low [69]. In a similar work MET (50 mg L−1) was completely removed in 50 min in a Fenton process and 3 min in photo-Fenton process using 5 mg L−1 Fe2+ ions and 125 mg L−1 of H2O2 [70].
1.2.4. Hormones A number of the natural and synthetic hormones are used in the treatment of various diseases like growth hormone deficiency, menopausal symptoms and cancer etc. These are constantly released into the environment, hence, a noticeable amount these hormones were detected in the STP andWWTPs of various countries. Synthetic estrogens, that is, 17-α-ethinyl estradiol (EE2), is used for oral contraceptives, and natural estrogens, 17-β-estradiol (E2), are commonly detected in ecologically relevant amounts in sewage effluents, sediments, surface water, river water, and in activated and digested sludge. Among these, natural and synthetic estrogens are already effective at the lower ng L−1 level [71]whilemost other chemicals having an estrogenic effect are biologically active at the μg L−1 level. And three hormones (estrone,
17-β-estradiol and 17-α-ethinylestradiol) have been surveyed along the different units of a municipal STP in Galicia, NW Spain [43]. Human excretion of E2 can reach levels as high as 5mg/day for pregnant women [72].
It was reported that a total estrogenic activity of 48.5 metric ton estradiol equivalent concentration (EEQ) per year contributed by livestock excretion in the United States [73]. The respective annual contributions by cattle, swine, and chicken manure were 45, 0.8, and 2.7 metric ton, respectively. E2 and Estrone (E1) account for N95% of the total estrogenic potency of natural steroidal hormone excretion by human beings and livestock [74]. Recent studies have shown that disposal of animal manure to agricultural land could lead to movement of estrogenic steroids into surface and ground water [75]. E2 has been found mobile and detected in runoff from manured land determined an average E2 concentration of 3500 ng L−1 in the runoff from a pastural land applied with 5 Mg/ha of manure (poultry litter). Further, the removal of hormones found in the STP and WWTPs effluents are performed by various processes viz. advanced oxidation processes, photocatalysis, and adsorption. For other countries, rivers in most reviewed cases had registered b20 ng L−1 hormones [76], except for U.S (872 ng L−1) [77]. Comprehensive studies in this area of research have been conducted in the United States [77,78], Europe [79], South Korea [76], Japan [80] etc.
During the X-ray imaging various types of X-ray contrast media agents are used to increase the visibility of internal body structure. The X-ray media investigated include iopamidol, iopentol, diatrizoate, iohexol, iomeprol and iopromide. All of these are non-ionic except the diatrizoate [81]. Mostly iodinated X-ray contrast media (Triiodinated benzene derivatives) are used in hospitals at high amounts [82]. For this purpose, usually highly soluble and biologically stable compounds are used and consequently disposed into the environment. Due to the highly resistant nature and low biodegradability, they are not degraded in sewage treatment plants andwastewater treatment plants. These iodinated X-ray contrast also have poor absorption capacity, hence, are excreted with no marked metabolic transformation and lead to the absorbable organic halogens (AOX) or absorbable organic iodine (AOI) in sewage treatment plant effluent, ground water and surface water [83]. The H2O2/UV system is themost commonmethod used for degradation of endocrine disruptors as E1, E2, EE2, BPA, parabens etc. as degradation is fast under generation of hydroxyl radicals [84].
1.2.5. Cytostatic drugs Cytostatic drugs, also known as antineoplastic agents, are the phar-
maceuticals used to treat various forms of cancers [85]. Some cytostatic drugs are also used to treat autoimmune diseases and to suppress transplant rejections. There are a number of classes of cytostatic drugs, such alkylating agents, anti-metabolites, alkaloids, and anti-tumor antibiotics. The majority of these drugs interfere with mitosis (cell division) to selectively kill fast growing tumor cells through a number of mechanisms such as inhibition of DNA synthesis. For example, the cytostatic drugs ifosfamide and cyclophosphamide were detected at concentrations of 24 and 146 ng L−1, respectively, by Steger-Hartmann et al. in sewage samples from a university hospital [86]. Similarly Buerge et al. shows the occurrence of the drugs cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide in the wastewater treatment plants and surface waters in Switzerland. The drugs were found in the WWTPs at concentrations around 0.3–11 ng L−1 [87].
1.2.6. Analgesic drugs Analgesics arewidely used drugs for treating acute pains and inflammation is thewidely used drug for pain relief and to treat inflammation. These include popular drugs as ibuprofen (IBN), diclofenac (DCF), naproxen (NPN), acetaminophen etc. and are regarded as one of most important and emerging environmental contaminantswith high persistence. The source of analgesics pharmaceuticals as contaminant is referred to anthropogenic activities including untreated disposal from
pharma industries and duming of human excreta into water bodies. It was been reported that the concentration of IBN, FCF, NPN etc. may range from 2 ng L−1 to 18 μg L−1 in river waters [88]. The occurrence of such drugs in drinking water supplies leads to serious human health concerns as limited literature is available for such pollutants retaining long in water system. The routine detection of such drugs in soil and water systems confirms their stability and resistance to oxidation by organisms and activated sludge systems. Thus advanced oxidation systems as photo catalysis, ozonation, Fenton, photo-Fenton, electroFenton and combination of these are required for assuring complete and safe removal [89].
2. Fate and removal
2.1. Factors influencing the fate of pharmaceutical pollutants in water
The fate and the behavior of the pharmaceuticals and their byproducts in the aquatic environment are usually not well known. The occurrence of these pharmaceuticals products in the environment is mainly due to release of WWTP effluents (human drugs) and veterinary substances into the natural water bodies and soil. These pharmaceuticals products first enter the surface water in trace amounts and also to the oceans and other aquatic environments bymeansWWTPs effluents release into oceans and rivers. Various toxicity studies revealed that the present pharmaceutical compounds do not show immediate acute toxicity towards aqueous flora and fauna as they are present in low concentrations. However their continuous release intowater bodies lead to high exposure and chronic hazards in long term. Especially in case of antibiotics, the slow exposure to microbes eventually increases the drug resistance in them which increases the danger for humans manifold. The various major mechanisms involved for removal in WWTPs include activated sludge treatment, algal bio-reactors, microbial reactors, membrane reactors and other biological methods. The physical and chemical properties as chemical & photo stability, solubility, volatility and bio-degradability of pollutant and operational parameters of treatment technology or plants as pH, time, temperature, mechanical controls etc. decide the fate of pharmaceutical contaminants in water. The Henry constant of pharmaceuticals is b105 showing almost negligible volatilization. In addition indirect photodegradation through the hydroxyl radicals generated by the solar radiation on the humic acid and nitrate like photosensitizers [3] are also responsible. The photodegradation is totally dependent on the intensity of the solar radiations, depth of the water body, composition of the organic matter and latitude as well as on season. Also this photo-degradation in WWTP is insignificant because sludge concentration is high causing high turbidity which blocks sunlight. In wastewater treatment plants, the main elimination processes are adsorption to suspended solids (sewage sludge) and biodegradation. The degradation of the pharmaceuticals by the adsorption is quite low. The adsorption is totally dependent on electrostatic interactions and hydrophobic of the pharmaceutical with microorganisms and particulates. In addition various parameters as type of reactor-continuous or fixed bed, flow rate, adsorbent concentration-surface area etc. decided the adsorption performance. So the acidic pharmaceuticals such as clofibric acid, bezafibrate, ibuprofen, fenoprofen having pKa values ranging from 3.6 to 4.9 have a low adsorption tendency on the activated sludge [90,91]. The degradation of the some pharmaceuticals in wastewater is partial, while some of them are completely degraded, giving rise to a mixture of by-products and some partially degraded drugs [92]. Other than the adsorption and photo-degradation, sorption can also take place during the sewage treatment processes. The biodegradation process is applied on sewage sludge, which is subjected to aerobic or anaerobic digestion by the various types of microorganisms present in the sludge. These pharmaceutical compounds in the sludge get degraded, although some of them may remain intact. After this these contaminate the groundwater or surface water in trace amounts. The biodegradation of
pharmaceutical contaminants is largely dependent on their structure, functionality and bioavailability. Additionally, pH, chemical properties, redox potentials also play a vital role. The short aliphatic chains can be easily degraded as compared to long-chains or aromatic molecules. The quantity and diversity of microbes in water also important and high retention times are advantageous generally for proliferation of microbes. The pH of water also has an effect on pharmaceutical molecule as well as microbial activity. In addition temperature and seasonal variations are also significant.
2.2. Various methodologies adopted for removal
Various treatment techniques as adsorption and photocatalysis have been used for removal of organic contaminants from water systems with excellent results [93,94]. Pharmaceutical pollutants differ from other organic contaminants because of following characteristics [95]:
i. Pharmaceuticals care generally formed by numerous complexmolecules with variable properties, structure, molecular weight etc.
ii. They are generally polarwith various ionizable groups and degree of ionization and behave differently at medium pH.
iii. Many of drugs are persistent in environment for longer time. iv. They have capability of entering cellular membranes and are persis-
tent. v. Pharmaceuticals are lipophilic & some of them are moderately solu-
ble in aqueous medium. vi. Theirmolecules once administered into human body, get distributed
and their structure can change during metabolic reactions
Wastewater treatment plants have been considered as the main units responsible or capable of removing pharmaceutical pollutants fromwastewater. Themain process involved is the biological treatment which includes conventional activated sludge method. However the removal capability is questionable andmany physico-chemical properties govern the final efficiency. Mainly the organic contaminants get removed by the activated sludge procedure as micro-pollutants can escape from it. Another biological treatment that is gaining some attention these days is the membrane process. Various researches are going on these biological processes to remove pharmaceutical wastes. Recent studies show the use of activated sludge method focusing on membrane bioreactor for the degradation of the pharmaceutical waste [96]. Layton et al. reported that about 70–80% of the steroid hormone E2 was degraded into mineralized product by activated sludge method in 24 h [97], while in case of EE2 hormone degradation results was inferior than the E2 Recent studies byWang et al. used membrane bioreactor treatment with reverse osmosis or nano-filtration membrane treatment for the degradation of the pharmaceutical products. This shows great results as compared to the conventional method system with increased removal rate upto 95–41% [98]. Another biological treatment, gaining some attention these days, is the removal of pharmaceutical waste through the membranes process. Various researches are going these days to remove the pharmaceuticals waste, personal care products and pesticides. After the treatment still the pharmaceutical molecules are detected in the effluents and regarded as a source in the drinking water. With the aim to remove these pollutants from drinking water, advancedwater treatmentmethods as ozonation, photocatalysis and Fenton oxidation are utilized for complete decomposition andmineralization of pharmaceutical pollutants. In general, three approaches are used for the remediation of the pharmaceutical wastes, which includes biological treatment of the waste, physical and chemical methods.Most commonly used are chemicalmethods,whichmainly include advanced oxidation process, ozonation and electrolysis. But sometimes biological and physical methods are also used. Fig. 2 show the diagrammatic representation of the methods used for the degradation of the pharmaceutical pollutants. The physical methods include
adsorption, filtration, reverse osmosis etc. Ozonation, electrolysis etc. are chemical techniques while microbial, enzymatic degradation and activated sludge methods are common biological treatment methods.
This is one of the cheapest and most frequently used methods, including adsorption by activated carbon. Mainly two types of activated carbon are used for these purposes, consisting of powder activated carbon and granular activated carbon [99]. Jaria et al. produced activated carbon from the paper mill waste and also obtained average 78% of adsorption of the pharmaceutical waste was obtained. In this experiment, three pharmaceutical compounds (sulphamethoxazole, carbamazepine, and paroxetine) were kept under the observation for adsorptional experiment [100].
Focus has been increased for developing newmaterials and technologies for environmental treatment. Many nanocomposite materials have been developed and focused in recent times with multi-use and find applications in biological and environmental fields [101]. In the past few years, there is increase in the use of the chemical methods for the removal of the pharmaceutical wastes mainly through the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). It includes the mineralization of the pollutants through some oxidation-reduction reactions. These processes are mainly based on the generation of the (•OH, •O2−, HO2•) radicals, with hydroxyl radicals being dominant [102]. These radicals generate several systems, which makes this process highly complex. Being the strongest known oxidant, hydroxyl radicals can easily mineralize almost every organic molecule into CO2, H2O and inorganic ions with an increase in the rate constant up to a range of 106 to 109 mol L−1 s−1. Different types of techniques are being used for the generation of hydroxyl radicals in advanced oxidation processes (AOP). Those may be created by UV-radiation, ozonation or by the use of radical initiators such as hydrogen peroxides.
3. Fenton processes for removal of pharmaceutical pollutants
Fenton-based oxidation processes utilize common and non-toxic reagents can considerably reduce pharmaceutical pollution by exploitation of solar energy. Fenton-type reactions have been identified as effective methods, which produce hydroxyl radicals by reactions between iron salts and hydrogen peroxide in acidic medium. The general scheme for Fenton and photo-Fenton reactions is represented in Eqs. (1)–(4).
The chemicals used are easier to handle and reactions rates for the reactions aremuch faster than the other conventional AOPs. Fentonprocesses can be utilized alone, may be combined with or integrated into other wastewater treatment processes.
Fe2þ þ H2O2→HO˙þ HO− ð1Þ Fe3þ þ H2O2→Fe2þ þ HO2● þ Hþ ð2Þ
Fe3þ þ H2Oþ hυ→HO● þ HO− ð3Þ
HO● þ H2O2→H2Oþ HO2● ð4Þ
Performance of Fenton oxidation reactions is largely dependent on operational parameters as pH, temperature, ration and concentration of Fe2+/H2O2, pollution concentration etc. Hydroxyl radicals generated in the reaction medium depend upon the concentration of H2O2 which means the higher the H2O2 concentration, more •OH radicals and this obviously also depends on Fe2+ concentration and operational parameters. However, high concentration of peroxide leads to formation of lesser active HO2• radicals which shows a scavenging effect. Similarly high Fe2+ concentration leads to higher radical formation initially but shows a scavenging effect at much higher concentrations. Thus ratio of Fe2+/H2O2 is important for ensuring optimum production and continuous availability of •OH radicals [103].
3.1. Homogeneous Fenton processes
Fenton oxidation can either be classified as homogeneous or heterogeneous depending on the catalyst used. In homogeneous system, whole reaction occurs in liquid phase and in heterogeneous system, reaction occurs on catalyst surface. During heterogeneous Fenton process, the adsorption and diffusion processes play an important role and prove beneficial for performance. The hydroxyl radicals can remove e− from any molecule to form hydroxyl anion. They are capable of breaking organic bonds with bond energy lower than 109 kcal mol−1 (for O\\H bond) is susceptible to oxidation. The first step is faster owing to rapid formation of •OHradicals but gets slower due to fall in Fe2+ ions and formation of lesser reactive •OOH radicals [104]. However the generation of •OH radicals and overall performance is enhanced by UV light irradiation during a photo-Fenton process. The photo-Fenton reaction is accompanied by generation of •OH radicals via H2O2 decomposition in acidic medium and via UV light. The pH is generally maintained at 3 to avoid precipitation of Fe2+ ions. In photo-Fenton process, the quantity of Fe2+ required is quite lower. In addition, recently solar light and artificial visible light has also been explored. Homogeneous Fenton and photo-Fenton reactions are widely utilized for water treatment and water disinfection.
Homogeneous Fenton reactions are disadvantageous because they require high iron content (50–80 ppm), limited pH activity and deactivation. This has diverted attention towards developing heterogeneous Fenton processes.
3.2. Heterogeneous Fenton processes
Heterogeneous Fenton processes have been developed as an attractive alternative to homogeneous system. The reactions occur on the
active sites on catalyst surface which prevents leaching. In addition to limitations of the homogeneous Fenton reaction as discussed above, acidicmedium is required for these reactions to proceed. Subsequent attempt to neutralize the system leading to precipitation of Fe3+ as sludge requires additional handling issues. In addition catalytic deactivation by complexation with effluents as EDTA, phosphate ions etc. are also an issue in homogeneous system. Thus utilizing heterogeneous Fentonlike solid catalysts such as [Fe(OH)2]+ [Fe(H2O)]+2, [Fe(H2O)6]+3, Ferrous polycation, Fe2O3, and α-FeOOH to extend the working pH range and avoid other limitations as recovery of iron after treatment. Various other iron based materials as Fe3O4 and ferrites have been explored which are effective and easily separable from water system [105–106]. Researchers have been focussing on developing new heterogeneous Fenton-like catalaysts and photocatalysts with minimal leaching effect, high catalytic performance and high stability. These solid catalysts inlude supported catalysts and non-supported catalysts. The supported solid catalysts immobilize the Fe species for preventing leaching. Heterogeneous Fenton reactions have been used to treat water contaminated with a variety of organic and biological pollutants and in organic synthesis. Such reactions as epoxidation, hydroxylation, dehydrogenation, and oxygenation also proceed under the action of heterogeneous Fenton reagent. Zhu et al synthesized polyhedral Fe3O4 nanoparticles by hydrothermal technique with {110} l6exposed facets. Under UV-Fenton system 96.7% tetracycline (TC) was degraded in 60 min which was quite high than polyhedral Fe3O4/H2O2 system (40%) and spherical Fe3O4/H2O2/UV system (28%). For polyhedral Fe3O4/H2O2/UV system TOC removal efficiency reached 56.5% after 120 min reaction [107]. Ma et al. [108] synthesized a Fe-N-graphene wrapped Al2O3/pentlandite composite from microalgae. The composite catalyst showed high Fenton activity which was supposed to be from synergistic effect of Fe, Al and Ni. It was suggested that the enhanced Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle initiates from enhanced e− transfer. This leads
to low consumption of H2O2 and higher •OH radicals generation. The organic radicals produced during Fenton degradation also facilitate Fe3+
reduction which was also supposed to be accelerated by N-doped graphene. The catalystwas reused for 12 timeswith nonoticeable losses in catalytic activity showing the long-term usability [108]. In summary, heterogeneous Fenton reaction hasmany advantages and long-term reusability. However inmost of researchwork done lab scale experiments have been performed but industrial scale use is still limited because of limited synthetic conditions, high cost and difficult designing of reactors. In the recent years novel Fenton catalysts have been explored for photo-Fenton, electro-Fenton, photo-electro-Fenton and hybrid processes combined with biological and microbial treatment for efficient degradation of organic pollutants. Some typical reviews have been published regarding Fenton, photo-Fenton processes discussing their different aspects, detailed information of the application in waste water treatment. Similarly many review articles have been published on various technologies based on advanced oxidation processes for pharmaceuticals pollutant removal. As far as Fenton processes are concerned both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems have been explored for Fenton and photo-Fenton processes. In this review we aim at covering the menace of pharmaceutical pollutants (types and complexities involved) and role of Fenton, photo-Fenton, Electro-Fenton and Photoelectro-Fenton processes (both homogeneous & heterogeneous) in degradation of these emerging pollutants. Various parameters and novelties have been reported which give a better insight into role of various mechanisms in the degradation process. In addition Various Fentonlike novel systems have been discussed involving Fe based materials and other catalysts without iron. The hybridization of Fenton processes with biological and microbial processes for enhanced degradation of pharmaceutical pollutants have also been compiled and evaluated.
3.3. Photo-Fenton process
3.3.1. Fundamentals of photo-Fenton process Photo–Fenton is one of the most effective advanced oxidation process used for the decomposition of the pharmaceutical effluents. Heterogeneous photocatalysis has been an effective treatment method owing to high degradation and mineralization efficiency in addition to low cost approach and greener methodology [109–110]. Combining photocatalysis with Fenton processes has been one of most successful techniques for high performance mineralization of organics. Moreover, heterogeneous photo-Fenton reactionshave emerged as efficient degradation processes due to high reaction efficiency and easier separation of photocatalyst from treated water to avoid secondarymetal ion/dye pollution Photo- Fenton processes is most notably studied in the last years. In the past few years, various studies have shown the efficiency of this process for the degradation of the various pharmaceuticals such as analgesics, antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs [111]. Photo-Fenton processes are process, in which the Fenton reaction is assisted by the UV–vis radiations from artificial sources or sunlight. In other words, the photo-Fenton reaction is combination of the Fenton reagents with photo-catalysts for the production of extra •OH radicals [112]. In this process, the photolysis of Fe3+ cations leads to Fe2+ ions in acidic medium and then a further reaction takes place between the Fe2+ and H2O2 in the presence of UV–vis radiations to produce hydroxyl radicals.
Themain advantage of this process is the regeneration of the Fe2+ by the photoreduction of Fe3+ as an additional source for the production of hydroxyl radicals. In case of conventional Fenton processes there is no regeneration of Fe3+. Actually, in the latter, the overall rate of regeneration and process efficiency are considerably low, as discussed elsewhere [113]. Nevertheless, the importance of the regeneration of Fe2+
through another step, namely the photoreduction of the photochemical organic substrate or its degradation intermediates has been pointed out by someauthors [114]. Other than Fe, other transitionmetals can also be used for catalyzing the reactions mentioned above, e.g. Cu. In this reaction system Cuworks as the photo-Fenton catalyst following the similar
route for the synthesis of hydroxyl radicals like a photo-Fenton reaction in the presence of radiations [115].
3.3.2. Types of catalysts involved Various types of homogenous and heterogeneous photocatalysts are
being used for the degradation of the pharmaceutical products. In the homogenous process, a number of iron species including FeSO4·7H2O, Fe(ClO4)3, K3Fe(C2O4)3·3H2O, and Fe2(SO4)3·H2O are used as the iron source for the production of the hydroxyl ion. And, hence, also used for the degradation of the various pharmaceutical products. For example, in homogenous Fenton processes for the degradation of pharmaceuticals lincomycin (LCM) and diazepam (DZP), the ferrioxalate or iron nitrate was used and also the efficiency of the process was also evaluated. The comparisonwas held between the two homogenous catalysts, which results in a higher effectiveness of ferrioxalate in relation to Fe(NO3) under UV-light or solar irradiation [52].
Similarly, in case of the heterogeneous photo-Fenton processes, various catalysts are being used for the degradation of the pharmaceutical effluents. Magnetite (Fe3O4) is most employed photo-Fenton heterogeneous catalyst which can be formed naturally by Fe2+ oxidation, chemical & biological reduction of ferric ions. Fe3O4 has potential to degrade organics but mineralization is achieved only in presence of H2O2 via Fenton process. In addition agglomeration is also an issue with Fe3O4 nanoparticles which reduces the catalytic performance. Iron pyrite (FeS2) is also an alternativewhich is beneficial as it provides two ferrous ions.
Catala et al. uses the silica supported iron oxide (Fe2O3/SBA-15) nanocatalyst for the degradation of the 15 drugs of abuse from the wastewater effluents with the help of photo-Fenton processes. The Fe2O3/SBA-15 cause the increase in the production of the hydroxyl radicals which further increases the degradation of the drugs [116]. The performance of the synthesized CoFe2O4 catalysts was evaluated in the photo-Fenton process of phenol and paracetamol degradation.
Gao et al. synthesized 3D ordered mesoporous copper ferrite KIT-6 silica as a hard template with high porosity and large surface area. This heterogeneous photocatalyst was used as the photo-Fenton catalyst for the degradation of the sulfonamide antibiotics. The catalyst shows elevated catalytic activity in the xenon lamp and can be used 5 timeswithout in the deterioration of its surface. The free radical capture experiments performedproves that a large quantity of hydroxyl radicals have been produced in the complex system of H2O2/mesoporous CuFe2O4. Fig. 3 shows the mechanism of the photo-Fenton process for degradation of sulphonamide through CuFe2O4/H2O2 catalyst [117]. Some other catalysts using the photo-Fenton process for the degradation of the various pharmaceuticals as Goethite (a-FeOOH) and metallurgical slag have also been used to degrade various drugs. Fe-doped CeO2 for the degradation of diclofenac, photo-assisted Fenton mineralization of ciprofloxacin (CFX), a broad-spectrum antibiotic used in human and veterinary medicine was studied using a modified laponite clay-based Fe nanocomposite (Fe-Lap-RD) as a heterogeneous catalyst in the presence of hydrogen peroxide and UV light [118].

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Utilization of nano-photo-Fenton catalysts in degradation of pharmaceutical effluents
sections.text:
Until now various pharmaceuticals compounds has been decomposed by the photo-Fenton processes. For example, Valcárcel et al. studied the drugs of abuse and other pharmaceutical compounds in the surface water of the Texas River and then also their degradation through the heterogeneous photo-Fenton processes. The authors includes 21 drugs belonging to 6 different classes cannabinoids, benzodiazepines, cocainics, amphetamine-like compounds (ALCs), lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), andmetabolites and opioids [119]. Similarly the effectiveness of the Fenton and photo-Fenton was also checked through the degradation of the two antibiotics sulphamethoxazole (SMX) and trimethoprim (TMP) in aqueous solution. The photo-Fenton processes show a greater extent of degradation as compared to the conventional
ones. A degradation percentage of 97%–100% was obtained for the SMX while a percentage range of 52%–75% was observed for TMP by photoFenton processes [120].
Shemer et al. compared the activity of the four oxidation processes by the degradation of theMetronidazole by UV and UV/H2O2. Oxidation of Metronidazole carried out by H2O2/Fe2+ and UV/H2O2/Fe2+ followed a second order behavior. An enhancement of degradation was observed when the concentration of the ferrous ions was increased using these processes. An increase of 20% in the removal efficiency ofMetronidazole occurredwith the photo-Fenton reaction as compared to the Fenton oxidation [110].
An antibiotic nalidixic acid belonging to the quinolones group was degraded by the photo-Fenton process in the dematerialized saline water (5 g L−1 of NaCl). The operational parameter under which the process was operated are pH ranging from 2.6 to 2.8, concentration of Fe ions was near 20 mg L−1 (optimum concentration for solar photoreactor [121] and the temperature was maintained at 30–40 °C.. In this case, two studies of photo-Fenton treatment of the real wastewater were performed, onewith an excess of H2O2 (kinetic study) and another with controlled H2O2 dose (biodegradability and toxicity studies). In the kinetic study, nalidixic acid completely disappeared within 190 min. In the other experiment with controlled H2O2, nalidixic acid degradation was complete at 66 mM of H2O2 consumed. Elimination of the worldwide Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug (NSAID) ibuprofen (IBP) was done through the photo-Fenton process with the use of the solar artificial irradiations. In this case, the photo-Fenton process accelerates the decarboxylation of IBP and, hence, a total depletion of the drug was obtained. Both decarboxylation and hydroxylation are the key pathways for the photo-Fenton process in degradation of the IBP as observed by other workers too [122].
In another study an iron-pillared clay (Fe-PILC) ion-exchanged with copper (Cu/Fe-PILC) catalyst was prepared for degradation of paracetamol (C0 = 100 ppm) via photo-Fenton process at near neutral pH. Under these conditions no Fe precipitation was observed and 80% mineralization was observed. In the Fe containing systems, addition of Cu is beneficial for oxidative degradation of organic compounds owing to synergism between two metals. In addition to normal Fenton intermediates, formation of Cu2+-•OH reactive intermediate leads to higher degradation of paracetamol. Also Cu+ activates O2 to form various reactive oxygen species. Only 3% leaching for Cu/Fe-PILC catalyst was
Fig. 3. The mechanism of the degradation of sulphonamide through
observed and it is reusable for many cycles with negligible loss in mineralization capability [123]. Similarly, iron nanoparticles were synthesized with solvothermal process having size from 50 to 100 nm. The catalytic activity of the as prepared samples was checked through the photo-Fenton process. Depending on the synthesis conditions, samples with magnetic properties consisting of magnetite (Fe3O4), or of a mixture of magnetite andmaghemite (c-Fe2O3), and samples with nomagnetism consisting of hematite (a-Fe2O3), were obtained. Complete degradation of diphenhydramine with 78% TOC mineralization was achieved at relatively low leaching of iron species from the catalyst to the aqueous solution (1.9 mg L−1). Complete degradation of the pollutant can be obtained at acidic pH even at very low catalyst load as shown in Fig. 4 [124]. Ampicillin (AMP), which is the first semi-synthetic broad spectrum penicillin that was released in 1961, has been detected in treated wastewater effluents worldwide at concentrations ranging from sub-ng L−1 up to 27 μg L−1, as well as in various environmental aqueousmatrices up to 13.7 μg L−1, highlighting its recalcitrance to conventional biological treatment. Nevertheless, the degradation potential of AMP via advanced chemical oxidation processes, which are widely considered as promising alternatives of conventional technologies, hardly has been investigated. Thus, this study aims at assessing the efficiency of solar photo-Fenton process at degradingAMP from secondarytreated wastewater effluents under various experimental conditions. The degradation rate of AMP via solar photo-Fenton oxidation fitted well the pseudo-first-order kinetic model. AMP was completely degraded after 30 min of treatment at various H2O2 doses (25–100 mg L−1) under acidic pH, while its degradation was pronounced at mild alkaline conditions (inherent pH) (100% removal after 5 min) he irradiation intensity of the solar simulator was determined using a chemical actinometer (2-nitrobenzaldehyde, Sigma) and it was found to be 63 W/m2. A 100 μg L−1 AMP solution was fed into the reactor, which is a compromise between a sufficiently high concentration to characterize the degradation kinetics using available analytical techniques, and a low enough concentration to simulate real environmental conditions, which are in the range of ng L−1 to μg L−1. Various research groups have been working on Fenton-like catalysts which are capable of working in wide pH range under visible light. In such direction, heterojunctions have been prepared with iron species. A Z-schemeheterojunctionα-Fe2O3@g-C3N4 catalyst formed usingmelamine and Fe based MOF. The catalysts was used for Photo-Fenton
CuFe2O4/H2O2 catalyst Reproduced with permission from [117].
degradation of tetracycline (TC) (40 mg L−1) under visible light (420 nm)/H2O2 system at pH = 5.5. The optimum composite FOCN0.45, shows 92% TC degradation with rate constant of 0.042 min−1. The CB of Fe2O3 is more negative than Fe3+/Fe2+ potential (0.77 V vs NHE) and thus electrons are excited by visible light to participate in the redox cycle and H2O2 to generate hydroxyl radicals. The accumulated electrons in VB of Fe2O3 have enough potential to oxidize the pollutant drug directly [127].
Various Photo-Fenton experiments for degradation of common pharmaceutical contaminants are discussed in Table 2. Many experiments have reported solar Fenton degradation of some drugs which is important for large scale and industrial applications of the Fenton processes. In additionmany limited literature is available in hybrid or alternative methodologies adopted for treating the water with pharmaceutical residues from UWTPs. In a pilot scale project a membrane bioreactor (MBR) was integrated with solar Fenton oxidation for degrading three antibiotics-SMX, ERY and CLA. In addition prevalence of antibiotic-tolerant bacteria, antibiotic resistance genes (ARG) removal efficiency was also studied. The MBR-treated water showed concentration of 5.5 ng L−1 SMX, 7.2 ng L−1 CLA and ERY was below limit of detection. Additional 100 μg L−1 was spiked for Fenton studies. After approx. 120min the concentration of SMX and ERYwas decreased below limit of detection and 84% removal of CLA was observed. The complete removal of ERY and SMX was observed with [H2O2]0 = 50 mg L−1 [159].
The photo-Fenton system uses the UV, visible or solar energy for accelerating Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle which decreases the demand for high iron sludge and also increases the oxidation potential. However certain limitations are still there as low light utilization and high cost of operation and reactor. In the further research, progress has been achieved in harnessing the light absorption potential via heterojunction formation, sensitization immobilizing on visible active materials for large scale applications.
3.4. Electro-Fenton process (EF)
3.4.1. Fundamentals of electro-Fenton processes Electro-Fenton systemwasdeveloped to overcome the limitations of
Fenton process. The conventional Fenton reactions can easily be improved and accelerated by electrochemistry. Versatile choice is available as far as electrodes are concerned and the system is energy efficient and environmental friendly too. Hydrogen peroxide is generated in situ during the cathodic reduction of O2 which obviously is an advantage as far as cost and storage issues are concerned.
This process includes the various steps that are as follows:
(i) Generation of H2O2 through the reduction of the dissolved oxygen at cathodic surface with the help of an electric generator as shown in (Eq. (5))
(ii) Generation of the Fe2+ ions by the reduction of the ferric ions (Eq. (6)). Then the latter reacts with added iron ions to produce the hydroxyl radical of the Fenton's reaction
O2 þ 2Hþ þ 2e−→H2O2 E0 ¼ 0:67V vs SHE ð5Þ
Fe3þ þ e− →Fe2þ E0 ¼ 0:77V vs SHE ð6Þ
The strong hydroxyl radicals (E0=2.8 V vs SHE) are then formed via Fenton reaction. Hence using a cathode with high efficiency for oxygen reduction reaction is desirable. EF process offers significant advantages over the simple conventional Fenton process such as there is no need of storage of H2O2 and also there is less formation of the sludge from the iron species and other complexes. Also it overcomes themain disadvantage of the Fenton process that is the uncontrollable synthesis of the H2O2 usually when operating around pH3. Furthermore, as use electricity is used as clean energy source, it does not create any secondary pollutants. Since Electro-Fenton processes are not using any harmful reagents, it is an environment friendly method for water and wastewater treatment. Along with those advantages it has some disadvantages, namely a gradual corrosion of the electrodes, hence, preventing unattended long term use. Further, there is large electrical power consumption during this process, which directly affects the cost of the wastewater treatment plants. However, in spite of these disadvantages it is being used in the variouswastewater treatment plants for the treatment of the pharmaceuticals, personal care products and various organic compounds.
Electro-Fenton processes can have two different configurations. In the first one, Fenton reagents are added to the reactor from outside and inert electrodeswith high catalytic activity are used as anodematerial, while in the second configuration, only hydrogen peroxide is added from outside and Fe2+ is provided from sacrificial cast iron anodes [164]. Electro-Fenton process can be classified into four categories depending on Fenton reagents addition or formation: cathode electroFenton process (EF-H2O2), sacrificial anode electro-Fenton process (EF-Feox), Fe2+ cycling electro-Fenton process (EF-Fere), cathode and Fe2+ cycling electro- Fenton process (EF-H2O2-Fere) [163].
Table 2 (continued)

Degradation was increased to 2 to 4 folds by modifying Fe3O4.
