[122]
3.4.2. Nano electro-Fenton catalysts-synthesis and design The efficiency of the electro-Fenton depends on the cathode and
anode materials used in the process. A cathode material should be appropriate for the use so that it can generate H2O2 efficiently. Furthermore, the cathode should possess a high potential for H2 evolution, because these processes are favorable in acidic medium [184]. In 2010, a sandwiched film cathode i.e., iron-chitosan/nickel activated carbon fiber iron-chitosan/nickel (Fe-CHI/Ni|ACF|Fe-CHI/Ni) was synthesized by Fan et al [185]. This film was quite helpful in controlling the generation of the ferrous ions and H2O2 supply. The iron-chitosan component of the sandwiched film cathode acted as the iron source. Many carbonaceous materials have also been used as the cathodic materials in the electro-Fenton processes, which include carbon sponges [186], activated carbon fibers [187], carbon nanotubes on graphite [188], boron doped diamond (BDD) [189], carbon/carbon nanotubes and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) [190]. A number of these types of materials used as anode and cathode for the depletion of the pharmaceuticals are mentioned in Table 3.
Along with the cathode, the anode material is also important for electro-Fenton processes. Until now, the most effective anodes known in anodic oxidation (AO) for pollutant removal are boron-doped diamond (BDD) thin-film electrodes. They possess some characteristics, due to which they are highly efficient as anode materials such as corrosion stability in high acidic medium, inert surface and enormously high O2-evolution overvoltage etc [191]. However, those anodes are costly and cannot be used for the large scale production. Hence, alternative materials like titanium oxide electrodes are being used in place of BDD [192].
Liu et al. synthesized the activated carbon fibers supported on the ferric citratematerial for the removal of an anti-inflammatory drug ibuprofen (IBP). Activated carbon fibers (ACFs) supported ferric citrate (Cit-Fe/ACFs) was used as the cathode while RuO2/Ti was used as the anode. 97% ibuprofen degradation was achieved within120 min. and 85% IBP removal was obtained after the 6th cycle of degradation, demonstrating the good reusability of the cathodic material. The result of the experiment shows a good efficiency of prepared Cit-Fe/ACFs cathode for the removal of pharmaceutical contaminants [181].
Le et al. synthesized the porous carbon cathode in nitrogen gas flow mixed with 1% oxygen by thermal treatment at high temperature. The porous cathode as working electrode alongwith platinum counter electrode was further utilized for the degradation of the paracetamol through the electro-Fenton process. The 30 mL aqueous solution of PCM (0.1 mM) and Na2SO4 (50 mM) as supporting electrolyte and FeSO4·7H2O (0.2 mM), as the catalyst were prepared by adjusting pH at 3.As shown in the Fig. 5 (a & b) the scanning electron microscopy results revealed a homogenous porosity covered the carbon fibers. The crystalline size of the electrode material was also improved with thermal treatment. The electro-catalytic behavior of the electro-Fenton process was checked with the help of cyclic voltammograms (CVs) as shown in the Fig. 5(c). X-ray diffraction patterns of electrodes treated at different thermal temperatures in 1 h under nitrogen flow mixing
with 1% oxygen is shown in the Fig. 5(d). Porous carbon felt (PCF) electrode presented such outstanding properties compared to nonmodified one (rawCF) like: a surface area 700 times higher, a better hydrophilicity, a higher developed crystallization and an expanded electroactive surface area as shown in Fig. 5(e). The new material proved its significant efficiency, once it was applied as cathode in EF process to remove PCM in acidic aqueous medium. The TOC removal was 51% in 2 h treatment, which was 31% higher than on raw CF as shown in Fig. 5(f) [193].

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Utilization of nano-electro-Fenton catalysts in degradation of pharmaceutical effluents
sections.text:
A number of experiments are performed these days, in which pharmaceutical waste is treated with the help of the electro-Fenton processes. Similarly, the studies were performed on the antimicrobials triclosan and Triclocarban by Sirs et al. They degrade the antimicrobials with the help of the four electro-Fenton processes by using the carbon felt or O2 diffusion cathode and Pt or boron doped diamond (BDD) cathode. The four electro-Fenton processes rank as their ability for the degradation of pollutants Pt/carbon felt N BDD/carbon felt N Pt/O2 diffusion N BDD/O2 diffusion and their ability to remove triclosan completely also follow the same order with Pt/carbon felt being themost effective. Similar resultswere obtained in case of the other antimicrobial Triclocarban [194].
Pourzamani et al. studied the electrochemical removal of the drug diclofenac with the help of a three-dimensional electro-Fenton (3DEF) process, where a composite consisting of magnetite (Fe3O4) nanoparticles and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) was used along with Ti/TiO2-RuO2 anode electrode. A maximum degradation of 98.52% was obtained with optimized conditions. The 3DEF system possesses a much higher chemical oxygen demand removal efficiency and H2O2 production capability, compared to the conventional ones. There is greater production of hydrogen peroxide as well as of hydroxyl radicals in the presence ofMWCNTs-Fe3O4 as a particle electrode. A high degree of stability and reusability was also observed in case of MWCNTsFe3O4 nanocomposite [175].
Similarly, another pharmaceutical pollutant acetaminophen (ACT) that occurs in abundance in various water bodies was also degraded with the help of the electro-Fenton process as well as with the photoelectro-Fenton process. The effect of Fenton's reagent was investigated to determine the percentage ACT degradation. The effect of the various parameters was also checked on the degradation efficiency of the reagents. As the pH of the solution was increased along with the increasing Fe2+ andH2O2 concentrations, there is an increase in the production of hydroxyl radicals,whichultimately increase the rate of pollutant degradation. Under the optimized conditions such as initial [Fe2+] = 0.10 mM, pH = 3 and initial [H2O2] = 25 mM a degradation of 99% was observed for acetaminophen (ACT) [195].
Propranolol hydrochloride, a widely occurring beta-blocker in water bodies, has been degraded by electrochemical advanced oxidation processes like electro-Fenton (EF) as well as by the photo-electron process.
In this process, it uses a using a single cell with air diffusion cathode (ADE) and a Pt anode for H2O2 electro-generation along with a combined system containing the above Pt/ADE pair coupled in parallel to a Pt/carbon-felt (CF) cell [174]. Some researchers also report some novel electro-Fenton reactions using new catalysts as carbon nanotubes.Magnetic single-walled carbon nanotubes (MSWCNTs) were utilized for degradation of diclofenac (DCF) from aqueous by heterogeneous electro-Fenton (EF). A lower concentration of 10 mg L−1 of DCF was used with 60 mg L−1 MSWCNTs. Adsorption experiments revealed a poor adsorption of DCF (18.7%) in 120 min indicating poor potential. For the adsorption process by MSWCNTs, only 18.7% of DCF removal was achieved at 120 min, which indicates an inadequate efficiency of adsorption experiments by the catalyst. Under electro-Fenton process 97.8% of DCFwas removed and 71.12% for CODwas obtained at an initial pH= 5 and current density of 20mA/cm2 [196]. Summarizing the facts, EF process is a 2nd generation Fenton system where H2O2 is electrogenerated fromO2 reduction at cathode and Fe2+ is regenerated for formation of hydroxyl radicals. To some extent EF process overcomes some major limitations of conventional Fenton process. However research is continuously being done to address certain EF limitations as low H2O2 yield and low conductivity or current density.
3.5. Photo-electro-Fenton process
Photo-electro-Fenton processes (PEF) are an upgrade to an already advanced electro-Fenton process, which utilizes either ultra-violet (UVA and UVC), solar, or visible light for the photoexcitation of the Fe3 + complexes formed in Fenton reactions. This route can produce a large regeneration rate of Fe2+ by (i) the generation of hydroxyl radical by Fenton reaction (Eq.(8)) and (ii) the regeneration of Fe2+ from other photo-reduction of Fe(OH)2+ and Fe(OOCR)2+, as shown in (Eqs. (7)– (9)), which is the primary Fe3+ species in acidic medium.
Fe3þ þ H2O→ Fe OHð Þ2þ þ Hþ ð7Þ
Fe OHð Þ2þ þ hυ→Fe2þ þ HO● ð8Þ
Fe OOCRð Þ2þ þ hυ→Fe2þ þ R● þ CO2 ð9Þ
In a pilot scale experiment during solar photo electro-Fenton (SPEF) process SMX (50 mg L−1) was degraded. The electrochemical cell for the production of H2O2 has a filterpress cell reactor with a BDD anode and a carbon-PTFE air-diffusion electrode (ADE) as cathode. Efficient 90% TOC removal was observed after 360 min of reaction. The main by-products detected were oxalic, maleic, oxamic and fumaric acids, while NH4+ and NO3− were the main inorganic nitrogen ions released during the process. Comparedwith EF process, the use of solar radiation enhances the SMX mineralization [197]. The degradation of antibiotic metronidazole (pH 3.0) has been shown to be boosted by sunlight collected by parabolic collector (CPC)in a Pt/air-diffusion cell in comparison to the same reaction in the dark [198].
The decomposition of sulfanilamide (100 mL, pH 3.0) solution was studied by photo-electro-Fenton (PEF) and electro-Fenton (EF) in a stirred tank reactor. This stirred tank reactor is equipped with a 3cm2 boron-doped diamond (BDD) anode and a 3cm2 air-diffusion cathode. In both treatments, mineralization was carried out by hydroxyl radicals formed at the BDD surface as well as in the bulk solution from Fenton's reaction between cathodically generated H2O2 and initially added Fe2+, whereas in PEF, additional photolysis of intermediates also takes place under UVA radiation. The influence of substrate concentration and applied current density on antibiotic decompose, degradation rate and mineralization degree was examined [199]. In another work an air diffusion mesoporous carbon electrode (ADE-MC) was used as cathode electro-generation of H2O2 for electro-Fenton and solar photo electroFenton removal of amoxicillin. The concentrations of Pluronic F-127™ (matrix-forming agent) and resorcinol-formaldehyde polymer (carbon
precursor) were varied to prepare three different mesoporous carbon materials. Finally, the ADE-MC were used for the mineralization of amoxicillin (50 mg L−1), allowing complete degradation and mineralization percentages of 55% and 85% with EF and SPEF processes, respectively. MC electrodes generate H2O2 in adequate amounts, thus providing a viable option to degradation and mineralization of other persistent pollutants. [200]
3.6. Sono-Fenton processes
3.6.1. Fundamentals of sono-Fenton process When the Fenton reaction is combined with the ultrasound radia-
tion, the process is called the sono-Fenton. Fenton reactions could be promoted by ultrasonic irradiation in sono- Fenton process with the rapid synthesis of ferrous ions and the production ofmore hydroxyl radicals from water without hydrogen peroxide utilization (Eqs. (10)– (11)). In general, pairing ultrasonic radiation and Fenton oxidation (sono-Fenton or US/Fenton process) can encourage faster pollutant conversion/mineralization due to (i) higher generation of •OH (ii) improved mixing and contact between •OH and pollutant and (iii) enhanced regeneration of ferrous ions. During sonication, the sound radiation caused the generation of hydroxyl radicals. Now upon the addition of the Fenton reagent, there is a generation of hydroxyl radicals and the Fe2+is oxidized to Fe3+ [201].When the sono-Fenton process is applied to organic pollutant degradation, a synergetic effect between Fenton's reagent and ultrasound takes place, which spontaneously decomposes Fe-OOH2+ to Fe2+ and •OOH. This isolated Fe2+ can react subsequently with H2O2, produce •OH again, and, thus, establishes a cyclic mechanism.
H2OþÞÞÞ→HO● þ H● ð10Þ
Fe OOHð Þ2þþÞÞÞ→Fe2þ þ HOO● ð11Þ
Adityosulindro et al. studied the degradation of the drug ibuprofen with the help of sono-Fenton and sonication process. The process of Sonolysis was hindered by the other effluents in the wastewater, however on the other hand sono-Fenton processes do not show any changes in the activity of Fenton catalyst. Hu et al. studied the degradation of the Metronidazole (MNZ) drug, through the sono-Fenton process. The nano-Fe3O4was used as iron source in the process along with hydrogen peroxide and ultrasound radiations. The addition of nano-Fe3O4 particles along with the ultrasound radiations has led to an increase in the production of •OH radicals and, hence, in the degradation efficiency [202]. A number of such pharmaceutical pollutants degraded by sonoFenton process are enlisted in Table 4.

sections.heading: 3.7. Utilization of nano-catalysts in sono-Fenton reactions in degradation of pharmaceutical effluents
sections.text:
Huet al. investigated the application of ultrasound irradiation driven Fenton processes in the presence of peroxydisulfate anion (S2O82−) for the elimination of metronidazole (MTZ) from aqueous solution. The degradation efficiency of MTZ improved by the production of (SO42−) from S2O82− at a redox potential of about 2.6 V. The parameters, on which the degradation of results MTZ depends was S2O82− concentration, Fe2+/H2O2 molar ratio and temperature [203].
In this study, the degradation of Phenazopyridine was performed with the help of the heterogeneous sono-Fenton process. The process includes the heterogeneous catalysts plasma-modified clinoptilolite (PMC) nanorods along with the US/S2O82−. A maximum degradation of 90.14%was obtained after 20min. The optimumoperational parameters for the Phenazopyridine degradationwere found and the drug degradation process followed the pseudo-first order kinetic. The radical scavengers decreased the removal efficiency of the drug confirming themain – OH and SO4− radicals role in the US/S2O82−/PMC process [206]. It's
difficult to remove pharmaceuticals at low concentrations due tomatrix effect. However, coupling of Fenton processwith other advanced oxidation methods lead to enhance the performance for low concentrations. Sono-photo-Fenton method was used for degradation of roxithromycin (RXM) and clarithromycin (CLA) at low concentration of 10mg L−1. The process thus involves UV light, in situ H2O2 production and ultrasound (US). For this ZnS quantum dots/SnO2 nanocomposites were used as catalyst. In absence of the catalyst poor degradation was achieved for UV, UV/H2O2, US, US/H2O2 and UV/US/H2O2 systems. With catalyst +H2O2 system only 31.35 and 36.4% of CLA and RXM were removed which increased to 61.24% and 65.5% in sono-Fenton process. However in photo-sono-Fenton process the degradation increased to 68.21% and 72.56% due to synergism of photocatalysis, Fenton and ultrasound. In addition ultrasound also generates hydroxyl radicals and decreases agglomeration [207].

sections.heading: 4. Fenton-like hybrid processes and systems: Overcoming limitations
sections.text:
Heterogeneous Fenton reactions have been able to overcome the limitations of classical Fenton processes andhaven efficient to a high extent for degradation and mineralization of pharmaceutical pollutants and other organic contaminants too. However in case of pharmaceuticals many complexities are involved as their complex structure, pH dependent chemical properties, stability and resistance to biological & microbial oxidation. In addition they are present in μg L−1 to ng L−1
concentrations which is generally difficult to remove by advanced oxidation processes due to matrix effect. However developing hybrid systems with combination of technologies have been useful for removal of pharmaceutical contaminants at low or trace levels. In addition numerous novel Fenton-like catalysts have been developed which are capable ofworking atwide range of pH, at low catalyst concentrations and in-situ generation of H2O2. In this section various heterogeneous Fenton-like processes coupled with other technologies for high performance mineralization of pharmaceutical pollutants have been discussed. A number of iron-based materials modified by transition metal doping, encapsulating with metal organic framework are usually used as Fenton like catalysts. These catalysts are also being used for the degradation of the various pharmaceutical pollutants as shown in Table 5.
Recent studies by Tang et al. show the synthesis of iron-based magnetic nanoparticles embedded into a mesoporous carbon hybrid (Fe@MesoC). The hybrid was synthesized from the Fe-based metal organic framework (MIL-100 Fe) by pyrolysis method. This Fentonlike catalyst was used for the degradation of the drug sulfamethoxazole (SMX). Fig. 6 shows the structure of the catalyst. A degradation efficiency of 100% and TOC removal of 54.5% was achieved within 120 min under optimized operating conditions [208]. Similarly, a large number of iron-based MOF derived catalysts has been used as Fenton-like catalysts such as such as MIL-100(Fe) [209] and MIL88B-Fe [210] etc.
Further studies on Fenton-like reactions show the use of the pyritebased systems for the degradation of the pharmaceutical effluents as Fenton-like catalysts. Chloramphenicol was used as the target drugs for the degradation bypyrite based Fenton like process. The degradation capability was checked at alkaline condition through the addition of Na2S to the pyrite H2O2 system. The availability of S(-II) promoted the generation of FeSn. Besides, S(-II) played a role in accelerating the Fe (III)/Fe(II) cycles. The potential of S(-II) activating H2O2 to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH). CAP removal rate increased dramatically to 100% with only 1 mM H2O2 on addition of pyrite. Na2S was used to create S (-II)-rich solutions in this study. CAP degradation through the pyriteH2O2 reaction under S(-II)-rich conditions was illustrated from
pH 5–10 in Fig. 7(a) shows CAP removal rate at initial pH 5–9, and under the strong alkaline condition. CAP was depleted with the effect of concentration of Na2S on degradation shown in Fig. 7(b). Surprisingly, Compared to the CAP removal in pyrite-H2O2 system under same pH conditions, the removal rate was highly increased when S(-II) was added [211].
Similar studies shows the synthesis of yolk-likemagnetic structured encapsulated in silica shell and surface decorated with copper nanoparticles as Fenton-like catalysts for the degradation of acetaminophen. Firstly, the non-sacrificial template synthesis of yolk-shell structure nanoparticles with magnetite cores was done. Then it is encapsulated with a mesoporous silica shell (Fe3O4@SiO2) via a modified sol-gel
process. At last the copper particles are decorated on the surface of the above prepared Fenton-like catalysts. The removal of acetaminophen are different for Fe3O4 (5.9%), Fe3O4@Cu (19.2%), Fe3O4@SiO2 (10.9%), and Fe3O4@SiO2@Cu (31.7%), reflecting the different in material structures. The decoration of copper nanoparticles makes the newly formed materials have higher adsorption capacity than those of the precursor materials. In the presence of H2O2, Fe3O4, Fe3O4@Cu, and Fe3O4@SiO2 exhibited comparable degradation efficiencies of 58.8, 65.3, 67.0%, respectively, after 120 min of operation. However, the yolk-shell structured Fe3O4@SiO2 showed a faster degradation rate, by reaching a similar result after 60 min, suggesting a greater catalytic efficiency than that of either Fe3O4 or Fe3O4@Cu [212]. Bimetallic Fe\\Cu on ordered mesoporous silicon (Fe-Cu@MPSi) was prepared through the magnesiothermic reduction methods. Its activity as Heterogeneous Fenton-like catalysts was checked through the degradation of ofloxacin (OFL). A degradation of 85% was achieved in 2 h in case of Fe-Cu@MPSi while it was quite low in case Fe-Cu@SBA-15 (69%) and pure Fe@MPSi (18%). Themain reasons for the excellent degradation abilitywas the interfacial effect of Fe and Cu on the surface of the catalyst, electron and mass transfer ability of mesoporous silicon-based support and the unique complexation of OFL and Cu2+. The TOC decreased to 67% after 300 min of reaction depicting the mineralization of the intermediated during this time (Fig. 8).
Dant et al used the sol-gel and an ultrasound etchingmethod for the synthesis of the yolk-shell structured Fe3O4@void@TiO2 catalyst. The as prepared NPs were used for the degradation of the drug tetracycline. Due to its high specific surface area and awell-defined hollow structure and also the synergic effect between TiO2 shell and Fe3O4 core, it exhibits a remarkable performance for degrading TC. Furthermore, the catalyst possess high magnetization and high recyclability capacity due towhich it can be used for 5 consecutive cycles andwith the advantage of its use in a wide pH range of 3–9. Fig. 9 shows the degradation mechanism of the tetracycline through Fe3O4@void@TiO2 Fenton like catalyst [228]. Another heterogeneous magnetic Fenton catalyst FeNi3/ SiO2 was synthesized for degradation of antibiotic metronidazole (MNZ) in presence of H2O2. With increase in concentration of pollutant from 10 to 30mg L−1 the degradation decreased from 95.32% to 63.14%. A solid-liquid interface was formed with H2O2 leading to high adsorption. The H2O2 was adsorbed onto surface and •OH radicals produced thus have better capacity to oxidize the pollutant [229].
Thus adsorption also enhances the degradation as heterogeneous Fenton-like reaction is combined by adsorption and oxidation. The surface adsorption also plays an eminent role in life time and migration of reactive oxygen species during advanced oxidation process [230–231]. However adsorption is also pH dependent and thus cautions need to be taken [232–235]. The role of adsorption studied in an experiment where degradation of drug benzotriazole (BZA) was performed using Fenton-like catalyst i.e. mesoporous Cu/MnO2 (MCM). The catalyst shows higher adsorption and catalytic activity than bare MnO2 and CuO. 89% removal efficiency for BZA was observed in deionized water
which reduced to 56% in waste water treatment plant effluent in 60 min at initial pH = 7.13. A mechanism was proposed as seen in Fig. 10 (a). This involves surface adsorption with Cu and a redox reaction with Mn3+. This was then followed by Cu\\Mn cycle based Fenton-like reaction. The adsorption was favored by interaction of surface ligand of BZA with Cu which facilitated the Mn4+ oxidation and the redox cycle. In addition the reaction was promoted by reactions between Mn4+/Mn3+ and Cu2+/Cu+. Eight degradation intermediates were generated as shown in proposed scheme in Fig. 10 (b) [236].
Further Yu et al utilized sludge derived carbon (SC) for heterogeneous Fenton-like degradation of ofloxacin (OFX). It was observed that SC treated with H2SO4 which shows that sulfate group facilitated Fenton-like degradation by lowering surface pH. The catalyst shows significant adsorption as 91.5% of OFX removal and 62.3% TOC was removed after 180 min adsorption and 540 min oxidation at pH = 6. OFX were degraded under the wide range of pH (3–6). The acid treatment had great influence on OFX removal- enhances the adsorption and lowering the surface pH [237]. In another work graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) supported iron oxide (CN@IO) as a Fenton-like heterogeneous catalyst. The catalyst shows high dark-Fenton activity. It was shown that g-C3N4 accelerates Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle which increases degradation of ciprofloxacin (CIP). In the dark, complete CIP (20 mg L−1) removal and 48.5% mineralization was achieved. The trapping of iron oxide into g-C3N4 also solves leaching problem giving it much stability [238].
Some experiments report coupling of technologies as Fenton and biological oxidation. In a recent work pharmaceutical waste water with high load (HSW) and low (LSW) was collected from industry and subjected to Fenton and biological oxidation. As a pre-treatment technology dark Fenton (DF), solar photo-Fenton (PF) and electro-Fenton (EF) were performed to reduce organic load. The untreated and treated waste water was then subjected to aerobic activated sludge for biological treatment. It was observed that PF+ biological oxidation system leads to highest degradation and mineralization. 84% and 82% overall COD removal efficiency was observed under PF + biological oxidation for LSWandHSW. The efficiencywas slightly less for EF+biological oxidation treatment [239]. There are numerous other ways to improve Fenton efficiency. In this direction oxygen vacancy promoted Fe2O3CeO2 catalyst for sulfamerazine (SMR) degradation. Within 75 min total SMRwas removed and surface boundhydroxyl radicals play an important role. The oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst promoted and accelerated electron transfer to promote decomposition of H2O2. The adsorbed O2 on vacancies also promote Fe2+/Fe3+ redox cycle [240]. Solar photo-Fenton processes are important for large scale and industrial applications. Exposito et al. worked on intensification of solar photo-Fenton system with ferrioxalate photoactive complexes and ultrasound for mineralization carbamazepine (15 mg L−1). Under conditions ([H2O2]0 = 150 mg L−1; [Fe2+]0 = 2.5 mg L−1/[(COOH)2]0 = 12.1 mg L−1; pH = 5), full degradation was achieved after 5 min and 80% of TOC was removed using a solar photo-Fenton system intensified
l radicals via Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycle, ultrasound also generates hydroxyl radicals via H2O2

Higher removal of MNZ (92%) was obtained using 3D-GN@Cu0 as the catalyst. The dissolution and deactivation of the active component of the catalyst was greatly slowed down through the encapsulation of zero-valent nanoparticles by the 3D graphene matrix. [244]
with ferrioxalate. However, no improvement in the mineralization using SPFF process combined with ultrasound was observed [241]. Some researchers also report removal of pharmaceutical pollutants at low concentrations as such studies are promising for real waste water systems. In this regard montmorillonite clay modified with iron oxyhydroxides (MGO) was fabricated as a catalyst for the degradation of naproxen (NPX) (10−5 M). The degradation efficiency of the NPX in mixture (NPX-MGO-H2O2) reached 100% in 60minwith a rate constant
of k= 10−1 min−1. UV light significantly enhanced rate with 100% degradation in just 10min. 90%mineralizationwas achieved after 5 h [242]. Use of heterojunctions with iron based semiconductors for Fenton-like reactions have also been gaining importance because of some advantages: solar activity, high performance, high rate of hydroxyl radical formation, in-situ generation of H2O2 and low catalyst dosage. Kumar et al. 2019 studied degradation of ATL in water in presence of magnetic fenton like catalyst B@C3N4/LiFePO4/CuFe2O4 and achieved 99.5% ATL
coupled with 1mMH2O2 with or without 3.85mMNa2S (Inset: pseudo-first-ordermodel ([pyrite] = 100 mg L−1, [H2O2] = 1 mM, pH= 8, [CAP] = 50 mg L−1), Reproduced with
n in the Fe@MesoC/H2O2 Fenton-like system, Reproduced with permission from [208].
(20 mg L−1) degradation in 60 min exposure to visible light. In the experiment a very low dosage of catalyst was utilized as compared to other photo-Fenton experiments with high mineralization [243]. Table 5 shows detailed information of various Fenton-like hybrid catalytic systems with excellent performance for various pharmaceutical pollutant removals. Many catalytic systems are able to degrade the pharmaceutical pollutants present in very low concentrations which have been supported by cyto-toxicity experiments.
Extensive researchhas beenmade on Fenton, Fenton-like andhybrid systems for degradation andmineralization ofwide class of pharmaceutical contaminants. In addition to bench-scale results or experiments, some reports also focus on pilot-scale experiments or hybrid technologies to overcome limitations of Fenton processes and high performance efficiency. Utilizing Fenton based methods as pretreatment step to biological oxidation produces promising results and has been receiving a lot of attention. As far as photo-Fenton reactions are involved research should be more focused on exploiting Sun as a source of energy for sustainable and cost-effective water treatment. Considering the fast development in research over Fenton systems, in order to scale up to industrial levels, fabrication of novel catalytic systems economic viabilities, combining or coupling of technologies and environmental performance are to be kept in mind. Pharmaceutical pollution is increasing and various methodologies have been adopted so far because of their complex chemistry. However new hybrid catalytic systems involving EF, PF, SF and PEF processes with other biological or advanced oxidation processes present a promising line of research in future for sustainable water treatment.
Fig. 9. Degradation mechanism for the tetracycline drug through Fe3O4@void@
5. Conclusions
The alarming presence of contaminants of emerging concern as pharmaceuticals and derivatives in water bodies has attracted substantial attention among researchers and environmental regulatory bodies because of their acute toxicity. Due to their complex structures and chemistry advanced treatment methods as photo-oxidation, Fenton and photoelectro-catalytic methods for their degradation in aqueous media. Second as concern pharmaceutical pollutants are present in very low concentrations which increase the risks manifold as highly efficient techniques are required which can work at such concentrations. Among AOPs Fenton processes have many advantages as easy operation, safety, cost effectiveness and use environmental-friendly reagents. Homogeneous Fenton systems have been losing interest because of limitations as narrowworking pH range and high iron sludge formation. As far as water treatment plants are concerned pharmaceutical pollutants still remain in treated water because of their resistance to conventional water treatment processes. Heterogeneous Fenton systems are beneficial and promising as they can work in wide pH, are recoverable and require low amounts of H2O2 and Fe source. As far as upgradations and novelties are concerned, fixed catalytic beds, iron based nanoheterojunctions, supported iron catalysts, Fe-ligand complexes, visible light assisted photo-Fenton process, designing of Fenton-like reagents and various combinationswith other techniques. In addition adsorption of pollutants and H2O2 or oxygen onto catalysts increases the rate of reaction by increasing the life-time for hydroxyl radicals. Photo-Fenton and electro-Fenton processes are more beneficial as they reduce the consumption and in-situ generation ofH2O2. Fenton reactions in general do not lead to high mineralization but they significantly increase their biodegradability. This allows combining PF, EF, PEF processes with biological methods as pre/post treatment strategies for removal of lower concentrations of pharmaceutical pollutants. In addition some experiments also present integration of photo-Fenton, electro-Fenton and sono-Fenton processes and optimizing the conditions and strategies to get out highest mineralization. Hence future research experiments should focus on integration of advanced oxidation methods with Fenton-based and biological methods utilizing solar energy with minimum energy consumption and cost for sustainable removal and mineralization of pharmaceutical and other emerging pollutants.
